qas.question: How does a referee check for a knockout?

answers.text: a referee will wave their hand in front of the wrestler's face

qas.question: What happens if all wrestlers are down?

answers.text: If nobody rises to their feet by the end of the count, the match is ruled a draw.

qas.question: If all wrestlers are down, how long do they have to rise?

answers.text: usually ten seconds, twenty in Japan

qas.question: What kind of match has to end in a knockout?
What is another name for a knockout?

context: A wrestler can win by knockout (sometimes referred to as a <a4_0>referee stoppage<a4_0/>) if they do not resort to submission holds, but stills pummels their opponent to the point that they are unconscious or are unable to intelligently defend themselves. To check for a knockout in this manner, <a0_0>a referee will wave their hand in front of the wrestler's face<a0_0/>; if the wrestler does not react in any way, the referee will award the victory to the other wrestler. If all the active wrestlers in a match are down inside the ring at the same time, the referee will begin a count (<a2_0>usually ten seconds, twenty in Japan<a2_0/>). <a1_0>If nobody rises to their feet by the end of the count, the match is ruled a draw.<a1_0/> Any participant who stands up in time will end the count for everyone else. In a <a3_0>Last Man Standing<a3_0/> match, this form of a knockout is the only way that the match can end, so the referee will count when one or more wrestlers are down, and one wrestler standing up before the 10-count doesn't stop the count for another wrestler who is still down.
